In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Certainly! Below is an implementation of the `wrap_string` function in Julia. This function takes a string as input and wraps it into multiple lines, adding a new line character each time the length of the current word plus the remaining characters up to the next space exceeds the specified `text_width`. The default value for `text_width` is 10.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    lines = []
    current_line = ""
    for word in split(text)
        if length(word) > text_width || (length(current_line) + length(word)) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line * "\n")
            current_line = ""
        end
        current_line += word * " "
    end
    if current_line != ""
        push!(lines, current_line * "\n")
    end
    return join(lines)
end
```

To use this function and see it in action, you can do the following:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there. This is a very long string that will be wrapped into multiple lines. Each line should not exceed 10 characters.
